title: Test: New global auto approve mechanism

labels.name: verified
labels.description: Verification succeeded

body:
Refs: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/261671

- [x] macOS @sandy081
- [x] linux @DonJayamanne
- [x] windows @rebornix

Complexity: 2


[Create Issue](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/new?template=blank&body=Testing+%23264223%0A%0A&assignees=Tyriar)

---

This depends on https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/264220 which is coming in a little late, hopefully it'll be merged/released when testing time comes.

Global auto approve has been renamed from `chat.tools.autoApprove`  to `chat.tools.global.autoApprove` in order to make it more clear that it's not a prerequisite to use other auto approve settings. Additionally, there's now an opt-in warning the first time a tool attempts to use global auto approve. Please test the following:

- The new setting and description is good
- All cases of the opt-in dialog work
  - You can disable the global auto approve setting to reset this state and see the dialog again once it's been approved

title: Warn about global auto approve, rename setting
body:
Part of #261671

This will show a modal dialog for any tool call that triggers global auto approve, forcing the user to allow it (enable) or disable. When approved a storage key will be added to avoid the warning again. This is a stripped down version of what I wanted to bring due to time constraints.

title: win32(installer): Normalize PATH handling and fix uninstall filtering [needs testing]
body:
<!-- Thank you for submitting a Pull Request. Please:
* Read our Pull Request guidelines:
  https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/How-to-Contribute#pull-requests
* Associate an issue with the Pull Request.
* Ensure that the code is up-to-date with the `main` branch.
* Include a description of the proposed changes and how to test them.
-->

⚠️ This PR updates PATH handling logic in the Windows installer.
Changes are verified with string-based tests (PowerShell), but I would appreciate further testing on real Windows setups.


## Summary
Normalize PATH handling in the Windows installer (`build/win32/code.iss`) and fix uninstall filtering:
- Trim trailing separators when comparing (`\` and `/`)
- Case-insensitive comparison
- Consider 8.3 short names (when available)
- Handle empty / semicolon-terminated PATH without producing malformed values

## Why
- Avoid duplicate PATH entries when the existing entry has a trailing slash or is in 8.3 short form.
- Ensure uninstall removes VS Code’s PATH entry (both long and short forms).

## How
- Add `TrimTrailingSlash` helper.
- `NeedsAddToPath`: explode PATH, normalize each segment, compare against long and short names.
- `AddToPath`: treat empty/absent PATH specially; respect trailing `;`.
- Uninstall: normalize `{app}\bin`, compare against both long/short, rebuild PATH cleanly.

## Before / After (examples)
- **Before**: PATH contains `…;C:\Program Files\Microsoft VS Code\bin\` → installer adds `…;C:\Program Files\Microsoft VS Code\bin` (duplicate).
- **After**: no duplicate added.
- **Before**: PATH contains `…;C:\PROGRA~1\MICROS~1\bin` → uninstall sometimes leaves it behind.
- **After**: long/short both removed.

## Verification
- Windows Sandbox, PowerShell dry-run (strings only; no system writes):
  - trailing slash present → `NeedsAddToPath: False`; `RemoveFromPath`: entry removed
  - 8.3 short present → `NeedsAddToPath: False`; `RemoveFromPath`: entry removed
  - empty PATH → `AddToPath`: `C:\Program Files\Microsoft VS Code\bin`
  - PATH ends with `;` → no malformed value produced
(Full installer tests can be run if preferred.)

## Risk / Impact
Low: changes are isolated to installer script and guarded when 8.3 names are not available.

I only ask for it's help when I'm stuck and I have to be very very careful to tell it not to make any changes because it misses the whole thing I am saying everytime as if it just skips parts of things. I can ask it for something and it try to do it and regardless of if that part is write it almost always messes with something else that it should not be touching at all. If I ask for help for example a header section I see that it has made edits to the footer too that messed up what I did and made no since to do and was not needed. ChatGPT runs circles around CoPilot because it if you will call this, listens to what I say and does what I ask and doesn't omit half o what I say like CoPilot does. CoPilot doesn't ever get it when it is making mistakes when I provide clarity. But I can make progress with ChatGPT because it build on the information I am giving it to achieve a better understanding. If ChatGTP get slightly off track, I can make correction or clarify and it does not go back make the same mistake over and over again. CoPIlot consistently does one thing, it fucks shit up over and over and over again. I know there statements it can make mistakes. But I amazed that this is supposed to have full knowledge of html and css code language but it stills doesn't know what is doing. It almost never gets things right. I can not trust anything it does or says ever. That's proven to me even thought ive ove rand over that it will be somehow helpful that is a piece of worthless crap that does more harm than good. If do mess up and go to it I always to look to another source to make sure what it saying or doing is right. The excuse it makes mistakes possibly doesn't cut it. I don't have this experience at all with ChatGPT. The only reason why I don't soley use that AI is because it is not in VS Code and is more difficult to constantly sent it code with no way for it to esssential live in side vs cod eto interact with what i am editing. And I pay for CoPilot and I have why I haven't cancelled it. I guess I just can't believe it is this worthless. body:

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 
Version: 1.103.2 (user setup)
Commit: 6f17636121051a53c88d3e605c491d22af2ba755
Date: 2025-08-20T16:45:34.255Z
Electron: 37.2.3
ElectronBuildId: 12035395
Chromium: 138.0.7204.100
Node.js: 22.17.0
V8: 13.8.500258-electron.0
OS: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100
- OS Version: windows 11

Steps to Reproduce:
There are many issues with Copilot that are making my life harder and causing me to disable it. For example:

- When I start typing, Copilot suggests something. I press the Escape key to dismiss it and continue typing, but it immediately suggests the same thing again. There should be a cache that tracks the last suggestion and prevents re-suggesting the same content if it was dismissed.

- If I delete a line and then start writing something similar, Copilot suggests the exact line I just deleted. The cache should track recent deletions and avoid suggesting the same content that was just removed.

- When I have multiple comment lines and want to write code after them, Copilot keeps suggesting more comments, even after I press Escape to dismiss the suggestions (same issue as the first problem).

- When I paste multi-line code, the cursor gets placed at the far left edge of the editor. This is especially frustrating in languages like Python or YAML where indentation is crucial. Before I can press Tab to achieve correct indentation, Copilot starts suggesting code, preventing me from easily positioning the cursor where it needs to be within a function. The workflow becomes: press Tab, press Escape, press Tab, press Escape. If I accidentally press Tab at the wrong time or more than once, I need to press Ctrl+Z, then Copilot suggests the same thing again, requiring another Escape, then Tab again. If my timing is off, it ends up typing unwanted suggestions and I have to repeat this process repeatedly or give up and use the mouse. Pressing Tab after pasting code feels like waging war with the IDE, especially when multiple Tab presses are needed.

Node.js: 22.17.0
V8: 13.8.500258-electron.0
OS: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100
- OS Version: windows 11 

Steps to Reproduce:
The issue is intermittent. I performed a bisect and confirmed that it is caused by the Copilot extension.

The scenario occurs when you press Ctrl+X at the same moment Copilot provides a suggestion. When this happens, the selected code is deleted, but the clipboard remains empty.

Consequently, when you move to another line and try to paste, nothing happens. Undoing with Ctrl+Z and repeating the cut operation doesn't fix it.

The workaround is to switch to a different editor tab and then return. After doing so, Ctrl+X works as expected. This suggests the race condition might be corrupting a temporary cache or state within VS Code.

title: [Bug] Git Worktree menu does not appear in command palette with git.detectWorktrees enabled over SSH
body: Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes - VS Code Version: 1.103.2 (Universal) - OS Version: macOS 15.6.1 (24G90) and Ubuntu 22.04.5 LTS (remote) ### Steps to Reproduce: 1. Connect to a remote Ubuntu 22.04.5 LTS machine (e.g., AWS EC2) from a macOS client via the **Remote - SSH** extension. 2. In the remote terminal, create a Git repository and a worktree using the command: `git worktree add ../new-worktree main` 3. Open the `new-worktree` directory in VS Code. 4. Set `"git.detectWorktrees": true` in your settings. 5. Reload the VS Code window. 6. Open the command palette (`Cmd+Shift+P`) and type `worktree`. ### Expected Behavior The command palette should display Git Worktree-related commands, such as `Git: Worktree`, allowing for easy management of the worktree from the VS Code UI. ### Actual Behavior No `worktree`-related commands appear in the command palette. ### Additional Context * The issue persists even after performing a clean reinstallation of both VS Code and Git. * The Git version on the remote machine is `2.34.1`, which meets the requirement for the feature. * Running `git worktree list` on the remote terminal correctly lists the worktree. * The VS Code developer console shows no errors related to `git` or `worktree`. * The issue persists even after setting `git.showOutput` to `always` and inspecting the output logs. No relevant commands or errors were observed. * Manually created worktrees are correctly referenced in the Source Control view (e.g., the branch name is displayed), but the specific worktree commands are absent. * This problem seems to be specific to the remote SSH connection environment, as it doesn't occur with local repositories.

body:
- Copilot Chat Extension Version: 0.30.3
- VS Code Version: 1.103.2 (Universal)
- OS Version: macOS 15.6.1
- Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode): agent
- Selected model (e.g. GPT 4.1, Claude 3.7 Sonnet): n/a
- Logs: 

Steps to Reproduce:

Note, I cannot reproduce this problem on demand, but it happens to me frequently. At least once per day.

1. Go to `Output` -> `GitHub Authentication` and you can see it is issuing log statements continuously. See logs below. 
1. Go to the Copilot icon in the bottom right and click on it. It shows `Remote index.  Checking status` with the spinner going continuously. I'm not sure if this is related, but it might be.
1. Disable the GitHub Copilot Chat extension and Restart Extensions and the problem stops.
1. Go to your account in the bottom-left and log out of GitHub
1. Re-enable GitHub Copilot Chat extension
1. Log back in to GitHub account
1. Check the `GitHub Authentication` again and the problem is no longer happening
1. Check the `Remote index` status again and now it says `Basic index` and the spinner is no longer shown.

title: $msCompile fails to match indented dotnet output

labels.name: help wanted
labels.description: Issues identified as good community contribution opportunities

labels.name: tasks
labels.description: Task system issues

body:
Type: Bug TL;DR: `dotnet` (sometimes?) indents error messages with a few leading spaces and this breaks the `$msCompiler` matcher. The `$msCompile` matcher doesn't work on the output from the following task: ```json { "label": "build", "type": "process", "command": "dotnet", "linux": { "args": [ "build", "--no-restore", "-p:TargetRuntimeIdentifier=linux-x64" ] }, "windows": { "args": [ "build", "--no-restore", "-p:TargetRuntimeIdentifier=win-x64" ], }, "options": { "cwd": "${workspaceFolder:SiteGen}" }, "echoCommand": true, "problemMatcher": "$msCompile", "presentation": { "reveal": "never", "panel": "dedicated", "clear": true, "revealProblems": "onProblem", }, "group": { "kind": "build", "isDefault": true } }, ``` However, swapping out the `problemMatcher` with the following _does_ work (on both Windows and Linux): ```json "problemMatcher": { "base": "$msCompile", "pattern":[ { "regexp": "^\\s*(?:\\s*\\d+>)?(\\S.*)\\((\\d+|\\d+,\\d+|\\d+,\\d+,\\d+,\\d+)\\)\\s*:\\s+((?:fatal +)?error|warning|info)\\s+(\\w+\\d+)\\s*:\\s*(.*)$", "kind": "location", "file": 1, "location": 2, "severity": 3, "code": 4, "message": 5 } ] }, ``` The `regexp` is taken verbatim from [your own source here](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/614287f64de39de2b2b2b9b185867187a150d0bb/src/vs/workbench/contrib/tasks/common/problemMatcher.ts#L1500), except I've added a `\s*` at the beginning. title: Expanding window alters display
body:
Type: Bug On mac, fullscreening visual studio code (or expanding the window so it fills most of the screen) will alter the display of the *entire* screen, adding multiple recurring darker lines horizontally across the screen. The first time this happened, the text was burned into my screen even running a different device, but replaced HDMI which fixed it (was using vscode before), but upon returning to what I was working on, fullscreening the window would bring back the same visual artifact (minus the screen burning, could be a cable issue idk) Running the recent beta of macos 26, which may be more prone to oddities. Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.103.2
- OS Version: macOS Sequoia

Steps to Reproduce:

1.

```make
default: # Entrypoint
	echo "Hello, World!"
```

The trailing comment `# Entrypoint` should render as a comment in VSCode makefiles, including in markdown blocks with the code type set to `make`.

Instead, VSCode renders GFM code snippets as plain text.

And Markdown previews render `default: # Entrypoint` as one continuous target name. Including the colon (`:`) token.

Markdown previews also corrupt backslash (`\`) escaped multiline expressions.

title: Console host / terminal tab will not exit after using `code` to open file or directory in new window, until new window is closed
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: **Yes**

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.103.2, `6f17636121051a53c88d3e605c491d22af2ba755`, x64
- OS Version: Windows 11 version 24H2 build 26100.3775 x64

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Close all existing Code windows and all existing PowerShell instances.
2. Start PowerShell, run `code; exit`.
3. Observe that the PowerShell console or the PowerShell terminal tab hangs.
4. Open Task Manager and look for PowerShell process. Observe that PowerShell has exited.
5. Close the Code window normally (not using Task Manager). Observe that the PowerShell console or the PowerShell terminal tab exits once the Code window is closed.

Expected behavior: Step 3, the console or the terminal tab should exit.

Steps to Reproduce (continued):

1. Close all existing Code windows and all existing PowerShell instances.
2. Start PowerShell, run `code`, then close the console or the terminal tab using the `X` button.
3. Start PowerShell again, run `code; exit`.
4. Observe that the second console or the second terminal tab exits normally.

There are other things to try, such as using `code path-to-dir` or `code path-to-file`. A simple description consistent with what I observe in all those trials:

- If the `code` command opens a new window (file or directory or just running `code`), then it will block the console host or the terminal from shutting down, until the newly opened window is closed.
- If the `code` command did not open a new window, then it will not block the console host or the terminal from shutting down.

Psychic debugging:

- The `code` command starts `Code.exe` (for `cli.js`). Let's call the started process `Code[1]`. It is monitored by the terminal tab.
- If `Code[1]` determines a new window is not needed, it communicates the action to an existing window, and `Code[1]` terminates (unless `--wait` is specified). This means if the `code` command did not open a new window, then it will not block tab close.
- If `Code[1]` determines a new window is needed, it will launch some other `Code.exe` instances. For reason unknown to me, one of them (I suspect `Code[1]` does, also it seems to be the one hosting GUI) causes the terminal tab to wait upon closing.

Normally, a GUI-subsystem program should be detached from the console. For example, running `Notepad.exe` then running `exit`, then tab closes normally. For unknown reason, `Code.exe` (and possibly, all Electron-based programs) did not break away from the console?

title: Feature request: Comprehensive Documentation for Built-in AI Agent Tools
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

Currently, there doesn’t appear to be a single dedicated page or comprehensive documentation covering the **built-in AI agent tools contributed by VS Code**.

Examples of such tools include:
- `insert_edit_into_file`
- `read_file`
- `file_search`
- `semantic_search`
- `create_file`
- `replace_string_in_file`
- `fetch_webpage`
- `vscode_search_extensions_internal`
- `getCurrentMilestone`
- `getReleaseFeatures`

These are mentioned in a scattered fashion across posts and examples (e.g., when explaining `*.prompt.md` usage), but there’s no central reference describing **their purpose, parameters, and usage guidelines**.

This makes it difficult for developers experimenting with agent mode to fully understand the toolset and its intended usage.

## Feature Request
- Provide a dedicated documentation page (or section) listing all built-in tools contributed by VS Code.  
- Include at minimum:
  - Tool name  
  - Purpose/description  
  - Example usage  
  - Notes on availability/limitations  

## Reference
A related community discussion highlighting the confusion:  
[Reddit thread](https://www.reddit.com/r/vscode/comments/1kkma27/is_there_a_comprehensive_documentation_for/)

This would help both new and advanced users take full advantage of the built-in agent capabilities.

title: Keyboard Shortcut for copilot voice-mode in chat-panel
body:
I need voice chat and to minimize mouse movement and keyboard interaction for medical reasons. there is a keyboard shortcut CMD+I for triggering walkie-talkie mode in the current file at the current line, but it's results are a significantly worse than voice chat triggered in the chat panel. For example, if I am in the middle of a scala file and say "make this `Foo` class be a `case` class", copilot will generate a new duplicate class immediately on the line I'm at instead, of altering the pre-existing `Foo` class, destroying whatever code was on the line and at the wrong level of indentation too. It's unusable. Whereas if I gave the same request from the voice mode within the chat panel, it correctly modifies the entire file in context. I only want to use the chat panel.

I looked and didn't see any keyboard shortcuts available for starting a voice chat walkie-talkie within the chat panel specifically. Please add, this is crucial for accessibility.

Also I don't understand why the shortcut for command+I is named `Chat: Start Voice Chat`, when it does not open the chat.

title: agente copilot non riesce a scrivere

labels.name: stale
labels.description: Issues that have not been triaged in an appropriate amount of time

body:
Titolo

Remote-SSH: Copilot non applica le modifiche ai file e genera processi server persistenti (extensionHost/ripgrep) su Ubuntu 22.04

Descrizione

Dopo gli ultimi aggiornamenti di VS Code/Copilot, in sessione Remote-SSH su Ubuntu 22.04:

Copilot non applica le modifiche ai file (lato server i file non cambiano, mentre modifiche manuali da terminale/editor funzionano).

Il server remoto di VS Code (~/.vscode-server) lascia processi extensionHost e ripgrep attivi ad alto uso CPU/RAM, anche dopo aver chiuso il client, creando processi persistenti (“zombie” in pratica, ma con STAT non sempre Z).

Il 28 agosto la macchina è stata bloccata tutto il giorno; al 31 agosto il problema persiste.

Passi per riprodurre

Connettersi a host Ubuntu 22.04 via Remote-SSH.

Aprire una cartella piccola del progetto (es. www/, non la $HOME).

Estensioni attive: GitHub Copilot (v1.364.0) e Copilot Chat (v0.30.3).

Chiedere a Copilot di creare/modificare un file (es. aggiungere funzione o snippet).

Osservare:

Il diff anteprima può apparire, ma il file su disco non cambia o non viene salvato correttamente.

Nel frattempo il server remoto spawna più processi: node ... --type=extensionHost e node_modules/@vscode/ripgrep/bin/rg ... che restano attivi e saturano CPU/RAM anche dopo la chiusura del client.

Risultato atteso

Copilot applica le modifiche ai file remoti come fa in locale.

Alla chiusura del client, i processi del server remoto si spengono o comunque non restano a usare CPU al 100%.

Risultato effettivo

Le modifiche Copilot non atterrano sui file (in locale funziona, in remoto no).

Restano processi server persistenti ad alto utilizzo:

zinga 28870 0.0 0.0 ... ~/.vscode-server/.../server/bin/code-server --start-server ...
zinga 28874 2.3 1.3 ... ~/.vscode-server/.../server/out/server-main.js ...
zinga 28930 0.3 0.9 ... ~/.vscode-server/.../server/out/bootstrap-fork --type=ptyHost ...


(in precedenza anche ripgrep/bin/rg al 90–100% CPU)

Cosa ho già provato

Workspace ridotto: apro solo www/ (niente $HOME).

Esclusioni in settings.json:

files.watcherExclude e search.exclude per **/node_modules/**, **/.git/**, **/dist/**, **/build/**, **/tmp/**.

search.followSymlinks: false.

Alias anti-frullatore (termina solo ripgrep quando parte in loop).

Disabilito Copilot via settings → i processi si calmano (quindi Copilot è concausa), ma mi serve attivo.

Aggiornati tutti i pacchetti (VS Code 1.103.2, Copilot v1.364.0). Problema invariato.

Locale (no Remote-SSH): Copilot scrive correttamente.

Ambiente (2 host reali)

Host A (alex):

OS: Ubuntu 22.04.5 LTS (Linux 5.15.0-152-generic)

VS Code: 1.103.2 (6f176361...) (client+server)

Estensioni: github.copilot@1.364.0, github.copilot-chat@0.30.3

Host B (ale):

OS: Ubuntu 22.04.5 LTS (kernel aggiornato)

VS Code: 1.103.2 (6f176361...)

Estensioni: github.copilot@1.364.0, github.copilot-chat@0.30.3

Nota: Localmente (non remoto) Copilot scrive correttamente. Il problema appare solo in Remote-SSH.

Evidenze (snapshot reale)
# Processi residui dopo chiusura client
ps aux | grep vscode-server | grep -v grep
zinga 28870 0.0 0.0 ... ~/.vscode-server/.../server/bin/code-server --start-server ...
zinga 28874 2.3 1.3 ... ~/.vscode-server/.../server/out/server-main.js ...
zinga 28930 0.3 0.9 ... ~/.vscode-server/.../server/out/bootstrap-fork --type=ptyHost ...

# Nessun Z, ma processi attivi che non si spengono
ps -eo pid,ppid,stat,cmd | grep 'Z'
(nessun risultato rilevante)

# In sessioni precedenti:
.../node_modules/@vscode/ripgrep/bin/rg  CPU ~90–100%
.../server/out/bootstrap

title: Vs code Ai tools lm studio interaction

labels.name: stale
labels.description: Issues that have not been triaged in an appropriate amount of time

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
There is something wrong with your or Lmstudios http://localhost:1234, connection. AI tools says the LLM does not return token count, when using LMstudio it does, and you can even turn it on in a setting.

Adding local Models is only going to explode, it is exploding now, if you did not know about what is happening in AI field.

Can you communicate with LMStudio these things, in LM studio, I would like it to state at the top if Token count is enabled/working for that model. This will help debugging in future. This needs to happen in the developer section, so that when you local host a model anyone can see if it is returning the token count.

Next to check it is not Ai tools fault. Can you coordinate with your team so that Custom Models do not need to return a token count, as in have this as optional. That way custom models that do not require token count returned for what they are doing, do not need it.

Lmstudio is far superior than ollama for selection of engines and Ollama has the worst storage of llms I have ever seen in my life, they are stored in a blob directory, with no identification at all.

Please please make LM studio your go to for ai tools, The files are well named, foldered, accessible and transferable between systems, as it is easy to see which llm you are dealing with.

Please make this a high priority, as local llm hosting is going nuts at the moment. If you were not aware of the AMD strix 365+Max chips and 128gb systems out there. Everyone who is anyone is now hosting locally.

The future is even better with local hosting, you get verbal access as well, so you can literally, stand anywhere that your computer can hear you and it will do your bidding, no need to even type like I am doing here, now. Programming locally just went ballistic.

Kind Regards Matthew

Either AI tools or LMstudio is at fault, cannot figure out which with out both parties talking to each other and seeing who needs to improve, whos at fault etc.

title: Test: Terminal tool auto approve improvements
body: Refs: #253268, #256780, #259668, #259672, #259760, #259763, #259765, #260573, #261126, #261674 - [x] macOS @deepak1556 - [x] linux @rzhao271 - [x] windows @bhavyaus Complexity: 5 [Create Issue](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/new?template=blank&body=Testing+%23264150%0A%0A&assignees=Tyriar) --- > [!IMPORTANT] > While testing this feature, remember this is a not just to improve chat UX but is also a security feature that helps protect the user. Previously chat's terminal tool auto approve was only a setting, this iteration has these improvements to test: - A new setting that allows disabling the feature outright - `chat.tools.terminal.enableAutoApprove` - A one-time opt-in with a dialog before the feature is enabled - Turn `chat.tools.terminal.enableAutoApprove` off and back on again to reset this state - UI entry point - This is the dropdown next to the allow button, the options provided depend on the command that is run - Reasoning for why it was auto approved below the tool call - A set of default rules - These are most conveniently viewed by opening your settings.json and adding the `chat.tools.terminal.autoApprove` which will fill in all default values - Rules are more path aware - For example, a manually added "scripts/test.sh" rule should approve the following: - `scripts/test.sh` - `scripts\test.sh` - `./scripts/test.sh` - `.\scripts\test.sh` - A warning shows about malicious content when `curl`, `wget` or pwsh equivalents are run - When the shell is pwsh, case is ignored when applying the rules

title: Test: Terminal suggest improvements
body:
Refs: #240232, #258512, #261016, #263167 

- [x] macOS @isidorn (zsh)
- [x] linux @roblourens (bash)
- [x] windows @mjbvz (pwsh)

Complexity: 4


[Create Issue](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/new?template=blank&body=Testing+%23264149%0A%0A&assignees=Tyriar)

---

There have been several improvements to terminal suggest this iteration.

Pre-requisites:

- Settings
    ```json
    "terminal.integrated.suggest.enabled": true,
    "terminal.integrated.shellIntegration.enabled": true
    ```
- Install `gh` CLI: https://cli.github.com/

> [!TIP]
> If `ctrl+space` isn't handled by your OS it will show terminal suggest which is useful or testing. Pressing it while it's showing will toggle the details window

Then test the following:

- Does intellisense show up fast for you? On Windows in particular a lot of performance improvements landed. If it feels slow (100ms+?), enable trace logging and provide the logs from the Terminal output channel
- Test a few commands on the git CLI
  - Focus on CLIs you use personally and look for a few examples that you aren't familiar with, is there any information you wish was shown that isn't?
  - Do SCM icons show up where appropriate? These new icons should be used: branch, stash, remote, tag, commit
- If you have the following utils or CLIs installed, make sure completions basically functions as you would expect. No need to go out of your way to test this list exhaustively, just what's convenient is fine.
  - `adb`

title: VS Code Theme Accent Color Ignored After Update – Catppuccin and Other Themes Affected

labels.name: themes
labels.description: Color theme issues

body:
Type: Bug I have the Catppuccin theme installed in Visual Studio Code. Under the extension’s settings, I selected the “Lavender” accent theme, and it was working perfectly for a long time. However, after a recent update to VS Code (I’m not sure if it was a major release or a bugfix), the accent color across VS Code is now permanently set to blue. This is not just an issue with the Catppuccin theme—the accent color is no longer following the chosen theme for any of the installed extensions. Steps to reproduce: - Install the Catppuccin theme extension. - Set the accent color to “Lavender” (or any other option). - Update VS Code to the latest version. - Notice that all accent colors are now set to blue, regardless of the selected theme or color. Expected behavior: The accent color should follow the chosen theme’s settings (e.g., Lavender for Catppuccin). Actual behavior: The accent color is always blue—even when switching themes or accent options in the extension settings. Is this a known bug related to the latest VS Code update? title: The "save as" popup dialog's behavior does not align with the primary side bar's Folders

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: simple-file-dialog
labels.description: Issues with simple file dialog

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:

<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: No

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.103.2
- OS Version: Windows 10 22H2

Steps to Reproduce:

1. have a working IPv6 connection
2. run `code --update-extensions` with at least one extension out of date

From what I can tell, on the CDN side this is the same issue as in winget (https://github.com/microsoft/winget-cli/issues/5693). Both `cdn.winget.microsoft.com` and `main.vscode-cdn.net` use the same CDN (`star-azurefd-prod.trafficmanager.net`).

In the VS Code UI, there seems to be a timeout and automatic fallback to IPv4, but the same is not happening with the CLI. It just hangs when trying to get `https://main.vscode-cdn.net/extensions/marketplace.json`.

On the CDN side, an incident should already be opened. But it would probably be good to have the same fallback logic in the CLI as exists in the UI.

title: Git: Remove problematic ruler at 50 chars
body:
The ruler at column 50, introduced in #201091, is wrong for all lines except for the first. Also, having it there breaks interaction with the (quite popular) rewrap extension:

https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=stkb.rewrap

The best solution would be if we could have different rulers for different lines, (50 for line 1, 0 for line 2 and 72 for the rest), but since that's not possible (or is it?), I believe dropping 50 is the best way forward.

Regarding the user experience, overflowing chars are highlighted anyway since #173195, so users who write too long subject lines will still be informed, even without that ruler in place.

Since I use rewrap all the time, and I commit things all the time, the current behavior is problematic for me.

"rewrap" uses the rulers to decide where to wrap text.

Before #201091, it wrapped at 72 chars, which was great!

With #201091 in place, it now wraps all lines at 50 chars, which is bad.

title: VS Code freezes on all file dialogs on Fedora 42 (Wayland/X11)
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: **Yes**

- VS Code Version: **1.103.2 (stable, x64)**
- OS Version: **Fedora 42 (GNOME 46, Wayland)**
- Kernel: **Linux 6.16.3-200.fc42.x86_64 # 1 SMP PREEMPT_DYNAMIC Sat Aug 23 17:02:17 UTC 2025 x86_64 GNU/Linux**

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open VS Code on Fedora 42  
2. Open any folder  
3. Try to open **any file dialog** (e.g., File → Save Workspace As…, File → Open File…, File → Save As…)  
4. VS Code becomes unresponsive (UI blocked) but the text cursor in the active editor **still blinks**  

### Expected Behavior
File dialogs should open normally, allowing selection of files/folders without freezing VS Code.

### Actual Behavior
- Any file dialog causes VS Code to stop responding  
- The editor UI does not react to clicks or keystrokes, but the blinking cursor in the active editor continues  
- No files are saved if trying to save a workspace or file  
- Happens every time, reproducible on fresh installs  
- Happens with `--disable-extensions`, `--disable-gpu`, and `--ozone-platform=x11`  

### Additional Information
- Tried both **Wayland** and **X11** sessions → issue occurs on both  
- No relevant errors in the developer console (`Help → Toggle Developer Tools`) before the freeze  
- Using latest Fedora 42 with GNOME  
- Kernel: **6.16.3-200.fc42.x86_64 PREEMPT_DYNAMIC**  
- Other dialogs (e.g., simple save of files) also freeze; not limited to Save Workspace As…
